title: Daily reminder that your game is flooded with bots.
body:
Playing a couple AI games because why not.

1st game: 3 bots.

2nd game: 2 bots.

3rd game: 3 bots.

4th game: 4 bots.

How long until you admit that you are helpless?

Sad riot. Just sad.

The problem is that RIOT simply is too cowardly to actually ban people for bad gameplay.
Bot behaviour, and might it be as stupid as you can imagine, is still considered what the regular human LoL player might play like.

In other games with actual moderation, people notice random pings on the map to fake activity (had a Katarina bot pinging random places with V, alwayw two, in a 1-second delay, every 30 seconds, to fake actual gameplay) or those weird up-down-up-down-up-down-up-down-up-down movements when the AI script is confused (had a Janna Bot doing that when two guys were next to her but "worked" when one was around) and that leads to a ban.

But having Jannas that sit under the tower, move up-down-up-down left-right-up-left-down-down-left, shield herself, stand still 5 seconds, place a ward for no reason, shielding her again and buys nothing is considered normal Bronze 5 gameplay, so of course it could not be punished, RIOT would lose 50% of their playerbase then.

It's ridiculous, but RIOT is not affected, neither is their income, so they won't do shit.

>Bot behaviour, and might it be as stupid as you can imagine, is still considered what the regular human LoL player might play like.

No, srry, they don't get to make that excuse.

The bots are:

* exclusively playing without Masteries, even if they have the required level to have them
* they NEVER buy wards
* They ALWAYS run down midlane
* They ALWAYS accumulate hugely negative KDAs with extremely small (if any) CS
* Their buildpaths ALWAYS start with either boots or a support item, and leave all other start gold unspent
* They stupidly autoattack regardless of the champion played
* They have predictable, consistent, nonsensical build-paths
* They do not chat or communicate in any way shape or form
* They exhibit long periods of inactivity, standing between towers motionless

There may be a few bot progrms that exhibit more sophisticated behaviour. So far, all I have seen, are the above described dumb drones. And not being able to weed those out, is just a pathetic display by Riot.

Other than actually holding up a huge sign readin "BOOOOOT!" what more do they need to identify them??

so wrong,you would be surprised what can one auto bot with latest elo buddy add ons do. He can dodge,evade,has masteries and different items every game for champion he is playing,can kite and use summoner spells.

Maybe next time, read the entirety of my post BEFORE composing a reply, okay?

I specifically pointed out, in the second paragraph, that there are bot programs that can exhibit quite sophisticated behavior...a fact that I am well aware of, as I happen to work in IT security, and autonomous software which exhibits pseudo-intelligent behavior based on complex data analysis, is quite a big deal in that area (especially when it comes to intrusion detection systems).

These sophisticated bots are far and in-between however.
From my personal observation, every bot that I could clearly identify as such, is a dumb program...essentially mimicking very simplistic commands, most likely based on a primitive analysis of the VRAM data.

Eliminating these, easily identified, bots would reduce the problem significantly.

You act like this is an easy fix.

This IS easy to fix, because a system that analyses games looking for malicious activity already exists for league, to nail down inters and other trolls in the punishment system.

The system is there, it merely needs to be adapted to scan for the specific behavior of the bots.

They do, and they have been but Bot programmers aren't dumb. It's an everlasting war between Riot and Bot programmers, as one side constantly tries to up their defense/offense against each other. Everytime Riot finds a way to do a mass ban wave of Bots, Bot programmers find a new way to cheat the system, which means Riot needs to find that exploit, and so it continues on and on and on. 

There is no one fix solution, it's an actual war between Riot and these Bots, each side building new weapons to face each other.

There would be merit to your point, if the bots we encounter now en masse were sophisticated programs.

They are NOT.

They are the lowest of the lowest, dumb programs, that do not even deserve being called "bots", because all they do, is issueing primitive click commands to the machine they run on, resulting in extremely dumb bot behavior which I describe [here](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/gameplay-balance/t7uU852J-daily-reminder-that-your-game-is-flooded-with-bots?comment=00040000).

This is literally 99% of the bots right now.

Not detecting those, is not because "bot programmers are not dumb", its just **pathetic and sad**. If Riot cannot even combat these primitive click-engines, how do they intend to fight actual bots?

You're really downplaying how hard it is to make an automated system that detects bots that also doesn't target new players. 

* Playing without Masteries? A new player who hasn't reached level 30 yet, or simply doesn't understand Masteries. Fringe case, but it can happen.

* Never buy Wards? What type of player buys Wards in a Bot game? Even without that, new players aren't big ward buyers either. 

* Running down Mid? Riot can't see that happening. They can see negative winrates, not the actual act without viewing each manually.

* Lotsa deaths and low CS? New players are bad at the game. To a certain degree, very new players are very likely in the aspect to do bad at both of those things.

* Unspent gold? Perhaps, unless someone skipped the tutorial. Another Fringe case, but with a huge playerbase, I wouldn't doubt it.

* Stupid Auto'ing? Can't detect that without manually looking at the game, can't be automated. New players are also bad at auto'ing.

* Predictable builds? New players normally stick to Recommended Builds, without knowledge/skill to adapt builds to what you need/want. Doesn't this one also negate the previous "Unspent Gold" one? 

* No Communication? I have normal games with players who never speak or ping. New players who aren't social people might be the same. 

* Periods of inactivity? I'm sure that's one of the things they use to help detect them.

The fact that any of those could be even doubted with a sense of new players, shows that this isn't as cut and dry as you think, hardly anything is. Riot has done Bot Ban waves before, and yet they keep coming back. Why do you think that is? Even if Riot can ban these bots, new bots will replace them, like they've done before. This is not an easy fix.

>You're really downplaying how hard it is to make an automated system that detects bots that also doesn't target new players.

Can you read what I wrote earlier before you reply?

#THIS SYSTEM ALREADY EXISTS!

**They don't have to make it!**
Automated analysis of ingame actions already is part of the player behavior system, it is used to detect inting and trolling players and punish them.

Except you can't just copy paste a system, which means it requires modification. Detecting bots and detecting int feeders are two different things, especially when it comes to making sure you don't accidentally ban new players. While one is it's own problem, the other is a sympton of the problem. 

Do you even know how Coding works? Becaue it really seems you don't.

>Do you even know how Coding works? Becaue it really seems you don't.

I happen to be in IT security, and my study program was with focus on system development, including low level coding (kernel modules), so yes, I do know how "coding" works, in fact more so than most people.

If you start to replace arguments with _ad hominem_ statements, I will simply ignore your future posts.

>Detecting bots and detecting int feeders are two different things

No, they are not.

In both cases, the system scans the logfile of the game for patterns of commands which indicate a certain behavior. While this is complicated, the system to do so is the same, only the parameters of the search change.

If the pattern matching is based on machine learning, which in case of Riots system it is, it is only a matter of training the system with the relevant input data, of which there is no lack, given the current situation.
